citation.article-title: Agromyces luteolus sp. nov., Agromyces rhizospherae sp. nov. and Agromyces bracchium sp. nov., from the mangrove rhizosphere.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Agromyces bracchium sp. nov.
Agromyces bracchium (bracchi.um. M.L. adj. bracchium like a twig)

Cells are aerobic, Gram-positive, irregular rods that form filaments (0.2-0.4 by 5.0-6.0 μm) or show elementary branching in the early growth phase and fragment into short rods (0.2-0.4by 1.5-3.0 μm) during exponential growth phase.
Colonies on PY agar medium are yellow, opaque, entire and convex, and sometimes penetrate into the agar.
Grows optimally at 20-30 °C, but does not grow at 10 or 37 °C.

Acid is produced from amidon, amygdalin, L-arabinose, arbutin, cellobiose, fructose, galactose, gentiobiose, gluconate, glucose, glycogen, lactose, maltose, mannitol, mannose, melezitose, melibiose, raffinose, rhamnose, ribose, salicin, sucrose, trehalose, D-turanose and D-xylose, but is not produced from adonitol, D-arabinose, arabitol, dulcitol, erythritol, fucose, glycerol, inositol, inulin, sorbitol, sorbose, tagatose, L-xylose or xylitol.
Aesculin, gelatin and starch are hydrolysed.
DAB is the principal amino acid of the cell wall peptidoglycan.
The cell wall is of an acetyl type.
The predominant isoprenoid quinone is MK-12 with small amounts of MK-13 and MK-11.
The predominant cellular fatty acids are anteiso-C15:0, anteiso-C17:0 and iso-C16:0.
The G+­C content of the DNA is 70-0 mol%.
Isolated from soil of rhizosphere of mangrove on Iriomote Island, Japan.
The type strain is IFO 16238T (=VKM Ac-2088T).
